content: Wikipedia employed a single server until 2004, when the server setup was expanded into a distributed multitier architecture.[47] Server downtime in 2003 led to the first fundraising drive. By December 2009, Wikimedia ran on co-located servers, with 300 servers in Florida and 44 in Amsterdam.[48] In 2008, it also switched from multiple different Linux operating system vendors to Ubuntu Linux.[49][50] In 2019, it switched to Debian.[51]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: By January 2013, Wikimedia transitioned to newer infrastructure in an Equinix facility in Ashburn, Virginia, citing reasons of "more reliable connectivity" and "fewer hurricanes".[52][53] In years prior, the hurricane seasons had been a cause of distress.[54]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In October 2013, Wikimedia Foundation started looking for a second facility that would be used side by side with the main facility in Ashburn, citing reasons of redundancy (e.g. emergency fallback) and to prepare for simultaneous multi-datacenter service.[55][56] This followed a year in which a fiber cut caused the Wikimedia projects to be unavailable for one hour in August 2012.[57][58]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: Apart from the second facility for redundancy coming online in 2014,[59][60] the number of servers needed to run the infrastructure in a single facility has been mostly stable since 2009. As of November 2015, the main facility in Ashburn hosts 520 servers in total which includes servers for newer services besides Wikimedia project wikis, such as cloud services (Toolforge)[61][62] and various services for metrics, monitoring, and other system administration.[63] In 2017, Wikimedia Foundation deployed a caching cluster in an Equinix facility in Singapore, the first of its kind in Asia.[64] In 2024, a caching data center was opened in São Paulo, the first of its kind in South America.[65]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The operation of Wikimedia depends on MediaWiki, a custom-made, free and open-source wiki software platform written in PHP and built upon the MariaDB database since 2013;[66] previously the MySQL database was used.[67] The software incorporates programming features such as a macro language, variables, a transclusion system for templates, and URL redirection. MediaWiki is licensed under the GNU General Public License and it is used by all Wikimedia projects.

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: Originally, Wikipedia ran on UseModWiki written in Perl by Clifford Adams (Phase I), which initially required CamelCase for article hyperlinks; the double bracket style was incorporated later. Starting in January 2002 (Phase II), Wikipedia began running on a PHP wiki engine with a MySQL database; this software was custom-made for Wikipedia by Magnus Manske. The Phase II software was repeatedly modified to accommodate the exponentially increasing demand. In July 2002 (Phase III), Wikipedia shifted to the third-generation software, MediaWiki, originally written by Lee Daniel Crocker.

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: Some MediaWiki extensions are installed to extend the functionality of MediaWiki software. In April 2005, an Apache Lucene extension[68][69] was added to MediaWiki's built-in search and Wikipedia switched from MySQL to Lucene and later switched to CirrusSearch which is based on Elasticsearch for searching.[70] The Wikimedia Foundation also uses CiviCRM[71] and WordPress.[72] The foundation published official Wikipedia mobile apps for Android and iOS devices and in March 2015, the apps were updated to include mobile user-friendly features.[73]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The Wikimedia Foundation was founded in 2003 by Jimmy Wales so that there would be an independent charitable entity responsible for company domains and trademarks, and so that Wikipedia and its sister projects could be funded through non-profit means in the future.[74][75] The name "Wikimedia", a compound of wiki and media, was coined by American author Sheldon Rampton in a post to the English Wikipedia mailing list in March 2003,[76] three months after Wiktionary became the second wiki-based project hosted on the original server. The foundation's mission is collection and distribution of educational knowledge under free licenses or public domain and promised to keep these projects free of charge.[9]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: All intellectual property rights and domain names about Wikipedia were moved to the foundation after its inception,[77] and it currently owns the domain names and maintains most of the Wikimedia movement's websites.[78] WMF is now the registrant of the domain wikipedia.org, owner of the trademark and operator of the wiki platform. It runs projects like Wikibooks, Wikidata, Wiktionary and Wikimedia Commons; it raises money, distributes grants, controls the servers, develops and deploys software, and does outreach to support Wikimedia projects, including the English Wikipedia. It also engages in political advocacy regarding copyright, press freedom and legal protection of websites from liability related to user content.[79]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The Wikimedia Foundation mainly finances itself through donations from the public, collected through email campaigns and annual fundraising banners placed on Wikipedia, as well as grants from various tech companies and philanthropic organizations.[11][81] Campaigns for the Wikimedia Endowment have included emails asking donors to leave Wikimedia money in their will.[82]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: As a 501(c)(3) charity, the foundation is exempt from federal and state income tax.[83][84] It is not a private foundation, and contributions to it qualify as tax-deductible charitable contributions.[81] In 2007, 2008 and 2009, Charity Navigator gave Wikimedia an overall rating of four out of four possible stars,[85] increased from three to four stars in 2010.[86] As of January 2020[update], the rating was still four stars (overall score 98.14 out of 100), based on data from FY2018.[87]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The foundation also increases its revenue through federal grants, sponsorship, services and brand merchandising. The Wikimedia OAI-PMH update feed service, targeted primarily at search engines and similar bulk analysis and republishing, was a source of revenue for a number of years.[88][89] DBpedia was given access to this feed free of charge.[90] An expanded version of data feeds and content services was launched in 2021 as Wikimedia Enterprise, an LLC subsidiary of the foundation.[91]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In July 2014, the foundation announced it would accept Bitcoin donations.[92] In 2021, cryptocurrencies accounted for just 0.08% of all donations[93][94] and on May 1, 2022, the foundation stopped accepting cryptocurrency donations, following a Wikimedia community vote.[94][95]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The foundation's net assets grew from an initial $57,000 at the end of its first fiscal year, ending June 30, 2004,[96] to $53.5 million in mid-2014[97][98] and $231 million (plus a $100 million endowment) by the end of June 2021; that year, the foundation also announced plans to launch Wikimedia Enterprise, to let large organizations pay by volume for high-volume access to otherwise rate-limited APIs.[99]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In 2020, the foundation donated $4.5 million to Tides Advocacy to create a "Knowledge Equity Fund", to provide grants to organizations whose work would not otherwise be covered by Wikimedia grants but addresses racial inequities in accessing and contributing to free knowledge resources.[100][101]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In January 2016, the foundation announced the creation of an endowment to safeguard its future.[102] The Wikimedia Endowment was established as a donor-advised fund at the Tides Foundation, with a stated goal to raise $100 million in the next 10 years.[103] Craig Newmark was one of the initial donors, giving $1 million.[104] Peter Baldwin and Lisbet Rausing, of Arcadia Fund, donated $5 million in 2017.[105]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In 2018, major donations to the endowment were received from Amazon and Facebook ($1 million each) and George Soros ($2 million).[106][107][108] In 2019, donations included $2 million from Google,[109] $3.5 million more from Baldwin and Rausing,[105] $2.5 million more from Newmark,[110] and another $1 million from Amazon in October 2019 and again in September 2020.[111][112]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: As of 2023,[update] the advisory board consists of Jimmy Wales, Peter Baldwin, former Wikimedia Foundation Trustees Patricio Lorente and Phoebe Ayers, former Wikimedia Foundation Board Visitor Doron Weber of the Sloan Foundation, investor Annette Campbell-White, venture capitalist Michael Kim, portfolio manager Alexander M. Farman-Farmaian, and strategist Lisa Lewin.[105]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The foundation itself has provided annual grants of $5 million to its Endowment since 2016.[113] These amounts have been recorded as part of the foundation's "awards and grants" expenses.[114] The Endowment pays the foundation for expenses the foundation incurs on behalf of the Endowment, mostly salaries of staff; in 2022–2023, this payment was 1.8 million.[115] In September 2021, the foundation announced that the Wikimedia Endowment had reached its initial $100 million fundraising goal in June 2021, five years ahead of its initial target.[4] In January 2024, the endowment was reported to have a value of $140 million.[116]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The foundation summarizes its assets in the "Statements of Activities" in its audited reports. These do not include funds in the Wikimedia Endowment, however expenses from the 2015–16 financial year onward include payments to the Wikimedia Endowment.[117]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: A plurality of Wikimedia Foundation expenses are salaries and wages, followed by community and affiliate grants, contributions to the endowment, and other professional operating expenses and services.[118][80]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
caption: Bar charts show expenses in each category generally on an upward trend between 2004 and 2024.

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
caption: Bar charts show salaries and expenses growing as a percentage, salaries to about 50%, while other categories are flatter or decrease. Hosting decreases from about 27% to about 2%

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content:
The Wikimedia Foundation has received a steady stream of grants from other foundations throughout its history.
In 2008, the foundation received a $40,000 grant from the Open Society Institute to create a printable version of Wikipedia.[119] It also received a $262,000 grant from the Stanton Foundation to purchase hardware,[120] a $500,000 unrestricted grant from Vinod and Neeru Khosla,[121] who later that year joined the foundation advisory board,[122] and $177,376 from the historians Lisbet Rausing and Peter Baldwin (Arcadia Fund), among others.[120] In March 2008, the foundation announced what was then its largest donation yet: a three-year, $3 million grant from the Sloan Foundation.[123]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In 2009, the foundation received four grants. The first was a $890,000 Stanton Foundation grant to help study and simplify the user interface for first-time authors of Wikipedia.[124] The second was a $300,000 Ford Foundation grant in July 2009 for Wikimedia Commons, to improve the interface for uploading multimedia files.[125] In August 2009, the foundation received a $500,000 grant from The William and Flora Hewlett Foundation.[126] Also in August 2009, the Omidyar Network committed up to $2 million over two years to Wikimedia.[127] In 2010, Google donated $2 million[128] and the Stanton Foundation granted $1.2 million to fund the Public Policy Initiative, a pilot program for what later became the Wikipedia Education Program (and the spin-off Wiki Education Foundation).[129][130][131]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In March 2011, the Sloan Foundation authorized another $3 million grant, to be funded over three years, with the first $1 million to come in July 2011 and the remaining $2 million to be funded in August 2012 and 2013. As a donor, Doron Weber from the Sloan Foundation gained Board Visitor status at the Wikimedia Foundation Board of Trustees.[132] In August 2011, the Stanton Foundation pledged to fund a $3.6 million grant of which $1.8 million was funded and the remainder was to come in September 2012. As of 2011, this was the largest grant the Wikimedia Foundation had ever received.[133] In November 2011, the foundation received a $500,000 donation from the Brin Wojcicki Foundation.[134][135]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In 2012, the foundation was awarded a grant of $1.25 million from Lisbet Rausing[134] and Peter Baldwin through the Charities Aid Foundation, scheduled to be funded in five equal installments from 2012 through 2015. In 2014, the foundation received the largest single gift in its history, a $5 million unrestricted donation from an anonymous donor supporting $1 million worth of expenses annually for the next five years.[136] In March 2012, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, established by the Intel co-founder and his wife, awarded the Wikimedia Foundation a $449,636 grant to develop Wikidata.[137] This was part of a larger grant, much of which went to Wikimedia Germany, which took on ownership of the development effort.[138]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: Between 2014 and 2015, the foundation received $500,000 from the Monarch Fund, $100,000 from the Arcadia Fund and an undisclosed amount from the Stavros Niarchos Foundation to support the Wikipedia Zero initiative.[139][140][141] In 2015, a grant agreement was reached with the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation to build a search engine called the "Knowledge Engine", a project that proved controversial.[142][143] In 2017, the Sloan Foundation awarded another $3 million grant for a three-year period,[132] and Google donated another $1.1 million to the foundation in 2019.[144]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The following have donated $500,000 or more each (2008–2019, not including gifts to the Wikimedia Endowment):

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The foundation's board of trustees supervises the activities of the foundation. The founding board had three members, to which two community-elected trustees were added. Starting in 2008 it was composed of ten members:

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: Over time, the size of the board and details of the selection processes have evolved. As of 2020, the board may have up to 16 trustees:[147]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In 2015, James Heilman, a trustee recently elected to the board by the community,[148] was removed from his position by a vote of the rest of the board.[149][150] This decision generated dispute among members of the Wikipedia community.[151][152] Heilman later said that he "was given the option of resigning [by the Board] over the last few weeks. As a community elected member I see my mandate as coming from the community which elected me and thus declined to do so. I saw such a move as letting down those who elected me."[153] He subsequently added that while on the Board, he had pushed for greater transparency regarding the Wikimedia Foundation's Knowledge Engine project and its financing,[154] and indicated that his attempts to make public the Knight Foundation grant for the engine had been a factor in his dismissal.[155] Heilman was reelected to the board by the community in 2017.[156]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In January 2016, Arnnon Geshuri joined the board before stepping down amid community controversy about a "no poach" agreement he executed when at Google, which violated United States antitrust law and for which the participating companies paid US$415 million in a class action suit on behalf of affected employees.[157][158]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: As of January 2024, the board comprised six community-and-affiliate-selected trustees (Shani Evenstein Sigalov, Dariusz Jemielniak, Rosie Stephenson-Goodknight, Victoria Doronina, Mike Peel and Lorenzo Losa);[159] five Board-appointed trustees (McKinsey & Company director Raju Narisetti,[160] Bahraini human rights activist and blogger Esra'a Al Shafei,[161] technology officer Luis Bitencourt-Emilio, Nataliia Tymkiv, and financial expert Kathy Collins); and Wales.[146] Tymkiv chairs the board, with Al Shafei and Sigalov as vice chairs.[162]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: As of March 2024 there are six committees of the Board of Trustees: the executive committee (Chair: Nataliia Tymkiv, as the chair of the board), the Audit Committee (Chair: Kathy Collins, appointed in 2023), the Governance Committee (Chair: Dariusz Jemielniak, appointed in 2021), the Talent and Culture Committee (Chair: Rosie Stephenson-Goodknight, appointed in 2023), the Community Affairs Committee (Chair: Shani Evenstein Sigalov, appointed in 2021), and the Product and Technology Committee (Chair: Lorenzo Losa, appointed in 2023).[163]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In 2004, the foundation appointed Tim Starling as developer liaison to help improve the MediaWiki software, Daniel Mayer as chief financial officer (finance, budgeting, and coordination of fund drives), and Erik Möller as content partnership coordinator. In May 2005, the foundation announced seven more official appointments.[164]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In January 2006, the foundation created a number of committees, including the Communication Committee, in an attempt to further organize activities somewhat handled by volunteers at that time.[165]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: As of October 4, 2006[update], the foundation had five paid employees:[166] two programmers, an administrative assistant, a coordinator handling fundraising and grants, and an interim executive director,[167] Brad Patrick, previously the foundation's general counsel. Patrick ceased his activity as interim director in January 2007 and then resigned from his position as legal counsel, effective April 1, 2007. He was replaced by Mike Godwin who served as general counsel and legal coordinator from July 2007[168] to 2010.

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In January 2007, Carolyn Doran was named chief operating officer and Sandy Ordonez joined as head of communications.[169] Doran began working as a part-time bookkeeper in 2006 after being sent by a temporary agency. Doran, found to have had a criminal record,[170] left the foundation in July 2007 and Sue Gardner was hired as consultant and special advisor; she became the executive director in December 2007.[171] Florence Devouard cited Doran's departure from the organization as one of the reasons the foundation took about seven months to release its fiscal 2007 financial audit.[172]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: Danny Wool, officially the grant coordinator and also involved in fundraising and business development, resigned in March 2007. He accused Wales of misusing the foundation's funds for recreational purposes and said that Wales had his Wikimedia credit card taken away in part because of his spending habits, a claim Wales denied.[173] In February 2007, the foundation added a position, chapters coordinator, and hired Delphine Ménard,[174] who had been occupying the position as a volunteer since August 2005. Cary Bass was hired in March 2007 in the position of volunteer coordinator. In January 2008, the foundation appointed Veronique Kessler as the new chief financial and operating officer, Kul Wadhwa as head of business development and Jay Walsh as head of communications.

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In March 2013, Gardner announced she would be leaving her position at the foundation.[175] Lila Tretikov was appointed executive director in May 2014;[176][177] she resigned in March 2016. Former chief communications officer Katherine Maher (joined Wikimedia in 2014[116]) was appointed the interim executive director, a position made permanent in June 2016.[178] Maher served as executive director until April 2021[179][180] and is credited with building the foundation endowment in her tenure.[116]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: As of October 23, 2023,[update] there were over 700 people working at the foundation.[181] Maryana Iskander was named the incoming CEO in September 2021, and took over that role in January 2022.[182]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: As of August 2024, the WMF has the following department structure:[183]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: A number of disputes have resulted in litigation[184][185][186][187] while others have not.[188] Attorney Matt Zimmerman has said, "Without strong liability protection, it would be difficult for Wikipedia to continue to provide a platform for user-created encyclopedia content."[189]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In December 2011, the foundation hired Washington, D.C., lobbyist Dow Lohnes Government Strategies LLC to lobby Congress.[190] At the time of the hire, the foundation was concerned about a bill known as the Stop Online Piracy Act.[191] The communities were as well, organizing some of the most visible protest against the bill on the Internet alongside other popular websites.

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In October 2013, a German court ruled that the Wikimedia Foundation can be held liable for content added to Wikipedia when there has been a specific complaint; otherwise, the Wikimedia Foundation does not check the content Wikipedia publishes and has no duty to do so.[192]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In June 2014, Bildkonst Upphovsrätt i Sverige filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Wikimedia Sweden.[193] On June 20, 2014, a defamation lawsuit (Law Division civil case No. L-1400-14) involving Wikipedia editors was filed with the Mercer County Superior Court in New Jersey seeking, inter alia, compensatory and punitive damages.[194][195]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In a March 10, 2015, op-ed for The New York Times, Wales and Tretikov announced the foundation was filing a lawsuit against the National Security Agency and five other government agencies and officials, including DOJ, calling into question its practice of mass surveillance, which they argued infringed the constitutional rights of the foundation's readers, editors and staff. They were joined in the suit by eight additional plaintiffs, including Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch.[196][197][198] On October 23, 2015, the United States District Court for the District of Maryland dismissed the suit Wikimedia Foundation v. NSA on grounds of standing. U.S. District Judge T. S. Ellis III ruled that the plaintiffs could not plausibly prove they were subject to upstream surveillance, and that their argument is "riddled with assumptions", "speculations" and "mathematical gymnastics".[199][200] The plaintiffs filed an appeal with the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit on February 17, 2016.[201]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In September 2020, WMF's application to become an observer at the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) was blocked after objections from the government of China[202] over the existence of a Wikimedia Foundation affiliate in Taiwan.[203] In October 2021, WMF's second application was blocked by the government of China for the same reason.[204] In May 2022, six Wikimedia movement affiliate chapters were blocked from being accredited to WIPO's Standing Committee on Copyright and Related Rights (SCCR) by China, claiming that the chapters were spreading disinformation.[205] In July 2022, China blocked an application by seven Wikimedia chapters to be accredited as permanent observers to WIPO;[206] China's position was supported by a number of other countries, including Russia, Pakistan, Iran, Algeria, Zimbabwe and Venezuela.[207]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In 2014, Jimmy Wales was confronted with allegations that WMF had "a miserable cost/benefit ratio and for years now has spent millions on software development without producing anything that actually works". He acknowledged that he had "been frustrated as well about the endless controversies about the rollout of inadequate software not developed with sufficient community consultation and without proper incremental rollout to catch show-stopping bugs".[208]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: During the 2015 fundraising campaign, members of the community voiced their concerns about the fundraising banners. They argued that they were obtrusive and could deceive potential donors by giving the impression that Wikipedia had immediate financial problems, which was not true. The Wikimedia Foundation vowed to improve wording on further fundraising campaigns to avoid these issues.[209] Despite this, the foundation has continued to come under criticism for running campaigns seemingly designed to "make its readers feel guilty." Such campaigns have additionally been condemned for, in 2021, being run in countries that had been badly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, such as Argentina and Brazil,[210] as well as for sparking fears in India that Wikipedia might be "dying".[211] This is despite the foundation being in ownership of "vast money reserves", in 2021 reaching its 10-year goal of compiling a $100 million endowment fund in only 5 years.[210]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In February 2017, an op-ed published by The Signpost, the English Wikipedia's online newspaper, titled "Wikipedia has Cancer",[212][213] produced a debate in both the Wikipedian community and the wider public. The author criticized the Wikimedia Foundation for its ever-increasing annual spending, which, he argued, could put the project at financial risk should an unexpected event happen. The author proposed to cap spending, build up the endowment, and restructure the endowment so that WMF cannot dip into the principal when times get bad.[214]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: As of June 2022, the WMF reported $239 million in net assets. It is expected to raise $174 million in revenue in the 2023.[215] Despite expenses on the foundation staff's salaries, there's a significant surplus left. To manage these funds, the WMF has created an endowment composed of investments and cash. This is managed not by the WMF but by the Tides Foundation.[215]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: The endowment aims to grow this capital to $130.4 million in the next fiscal year. However, there has been controversy over the administration of the funds. While the Tides Foundation has promised to become a more transparent 501(c)(3) organization to reveal how it manages funds, details on expenses and salaries are still lacking seven years later. Additionally, the WMF's salary costs have risen from $7 million in 2010/11 to $88 million in 2021/22.[215]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: Knowledge Engine was a search engine project initiated in 2015 by WMF to locate and display verifiable and trustworthy information on the Internet.[216] The KE's goal was to be less reliant on traditional search engines. It was funded with a $250,000 grant from the Knight Foundation.[217] Some perceived the project as a scandal, mainly because it was conceived in secrecy, and the project proposal was even a surprise to some staff, in contrast with a general culture of transparency in the organization and on the projects. Some of the information available to the community was received through leaked documents published by The Signpost in 2016.[218][216] Following this dispute, Executive Director Lila Tretikov resigned.[219][220][221]

title: Wikimedia Foundation - Wikipedia
content: In 2022, the WMF announced new recipients for its "knowledge equity grants".[215] The endowment aims to grow this capital to $130.4 million in the next fiscal year. Some of these funds are allocated to the knowledge equity fund, which provides grants.[215]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
section: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025)
content: The following is a timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2023–present) in 2025.

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
section: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025)
content: This timeline is a dynamic and fluid list, and as such may never satisfy criteria of completeness. Moreover, some events may only be fully understood and/or discovered in retrospect.

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Joint Darfur Force (JDF) said it had killed 462 Rapid Support Forces (RSF) fighters including six commanders in a failed attack on Al-Malha, North Darfur. In addition, three vehicles were destroyed. The remaining unit under Ali Rizqallah Al-Safana retreated. The JDF also called on the RSF to surrender to the JDF or the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF).[1]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed that RSF brigadier general Ibrahim Delib was killed along with 32 RSF fighters, including a Mauritanian national, after a drone being launched by the group misfired in El Fasher.[2]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed by RSF shelling on the Saudi Hospital in El Fasher.[3] Four others were killed by RSF shelling in Omdurman.[4]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Ten people were killed in an SAF airstrike in Khartoum.[5]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF and the JDF claimed to have deflected an RSF assault on El Fasher that came from the east and southeast of the city. The JDF also intercepted a weapons convoy for the RSF, arresting both Sudanese and Libyan nationals.[6]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The United States officially declared that the RSF had committed genocide and imposed sanctions on Hemedti.[7]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the administrative center of Ombadda as well as Al-Shagla and the western section of the Al-Fitaihab neighborhood of Omdurman from the RSF. It also claimed to have freed three captive officers in Al-Fitaihab in a special operation that left more than 20 RSF militants dead, including a commander.[8]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Four people were killed in an SAF airstrike on the Fata Borno IDP camp in Kutum, North Darfur.[9]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the town of Haj Abdallah in Gezira State, 58 kilometers from Wad Madani, and the village of Mahalla, 13 kilometers from Wad Madani, from the RSF.[10]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the town of Al-Shabarqa in Gezira State, 13 kilometers east of Wad Madani, from the RSF.[11]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the town of Um al-Qura in Gezira State, 40 kilometers east of Wad Madani, from the RSF, while the SAF-allied Sudan Shield Forces retook Wad al-Abyad, 20 kilometres from the Hantoub bridge.[12]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 26 people were killed in an attack by the Sudan Shield Forces on the village of Tayba in Gezira State.[13]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook Wad Madani, the capital of Gezira State.[14]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Sixteen people were killed by RSF shelling on the Zamzam IDP camp in North Darfur.[15]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the Al-Rawad residential complex in Khartoum from the RSF.[16]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 120 people were killed by shelling in western Omdurman.[17]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Merowe Dam power station was damaged by RSF drones, causing a fire at the facility and power outages as far as Shendi, Port Sudan, Atbara and Omdurman.[18]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook Karkaraia and Hajar al-Jawad, on the road between Dalang and Kadugli in South Kordofan, from the SPLM-N (al-Hilu).[19]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Thirteen people were killed by the SAF and allied militias in an attack on the informal settlement of Kambo Tayba in Gezira State.[20]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The JDF claimed to have killed hundreds of RSF militants, destroyed 262 vehicles, and captured 21 militants and 67 vehicles during clashes in Al-Malha and Halaf in North Darfur.[21]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 18 people were killed in attacks by the Sudan Shield Forces on the Shukaba camp and Camp 16 in Gezira State.[22]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 120 people were killed in an RSF attack on a civilian convoy being escorted by the Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) and the Gathering of Sudan Liberation Forces (GSLF) near Kabkabiya, North Darfur.[23]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Nine people were killed in attacks by the SAF and the RSF on members of the Kanabi community, who mostly originate from Darfur, in Abu Gouta, Gezira State.[24] Fifteen people were killed in an RSF attack on the village of Al-Khizan in Abu Gouta.[25]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sultan Ali Dinar Palace Museum in El Fasher was shelled by the RSF, causing a fire that heavily damaged the structure and destroyed its contents and furniture.[26]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Senior US officials reported that the SAF had recently used chemical weapons against the RSF in rural areas at least twice.[27] The US also sanctioned SAF chief General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan for the army's conduct in the war.[28]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF said that it attacked fighters and vehicles in Kabkabiya belonging to the JDF between the SLM-Al Nur and the GSLF. The RSF called for a joint committee to investigate the incident.[29]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Forty people were killed in an RSF attack on the village of Jebel Hilla in North Darfur.[30]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Six drones struck the Al-Shawak power station in Gedaref State, injuring civil defence personnel and causing blackouts across the state and in Kassala State. Other drones hit the Gedaref state water station while another crashed near a bus station along the Gedaref-Kassala-Port Sudan highway.[31]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF reached the Al-Shukri junction in Shambat, Khartoum Bahri, while the RSF retreated by one kilometer southwards to the Hassan Ibrahim Malik University City.[32] At least three people were killed by RSF shelling in Omdurman.[33]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have taken Al-Hallaf, Drishaqi and Mao in North Darfur.[34]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 11 people were killed by RSF shelling on the Abu Shouk IDP camp in El Fasher.[35]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: A coalition of SAF and allied forces claimed to have repelled two RSF incursions from Libya in North Darfur near the tri-border area with Chad and Libya, killing a total of over 950 fighters, destroying 61 vehicles, and capturing 78 others that were equipped with advanced weaponry.[36]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sudanese Revolutionary Front expelled the United Popular Front from its member groups after the UPF accused the alliance of being unduly influenced by the RSF.[37]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: SAF units besieged at the Signal Corps garrison in Khartoum Bahri launched their first major offensive since September 2024, forcing the RSF to withdraw east towards the Kafouri neighborhood. The SAF also retook Abboud Park in Khartoum Bahri and the Juwayriyah School and the African Council Schools in Al Safiya district.[38]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF issued a 48-hour ultimatum for the SAF to withdraw from El Fasher.[39]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF launched an offensive towards the El-Jeili oil refinery and retook the Rotana Mills southeast of the facility.[40]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The El-Jeili oil refinery caught fire with smoke being seen from Omdurman and Khartoum Bahri. The SAF claimed that the RSF had set fire to the facility, while the RSF claimed that it caught fire due to incendiary barrel bombs dropped by the Sudanese Air Force.[41]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed by RSF shelling on the Abu Shouk IDP camp.[42]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: An indefinite strike was launched by employees of the Bashair Hospital in Khartoum after an RSF member opened fire inside the facility the previous day.[43]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 70 people were killed in an RSF drone strike on the maternity ward of the Saudi Hospital in El Fasher that also destroyed its emergency department.[44][45]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have broken the siege around the Signal Corp's base in Khartoum. The RSF denied the claims.[46] The SAF also claimed to have broken the siege around its General Headquarters in Khartoum and retook the El-Jeili oil refinery.[47]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF and allied militias repelled an RSF attack on El Fasher following the expiration of the latter's ultimatum for the SAF to withdraw. The JDF claimed it had killed more than 400 RSF militants, destroyed more than 25 vehicles and captured 30 others.[48]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Ayub Osman Nahar resigned as an advisor to Hemedti, saying that he refused to be part of the RSF's atrocities against civilians and accusing the group of burning villages and killing civilians in North Darfur and Gezira State.[49]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have pushed into parts of eastern Khartoum near the Al-Rabat College in Burri district, advanced through large portions of the Al-Azba, Kafouri, Ad Babaker, and Ramallah neighborhoods of Khartoum North, and continued their advances towards the El Mek Nimr Bridge. They also claimed to have deployed troops to hold several neighborhoods under their control.[50]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: More than 100 people were killed in an RSF attack on the village of Broush in North Darfur.[51]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have seized the RSF's Medical Directorate located in the former SAF Paratroopers base in Shambat, as well as the Blue and Bashir Towers in Khartoum Bahri.[52]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF announced the death in action of one of its senior commanders, Rahmtalla al-Mahdi, also known as "Jalha", along with his brother. The two were reportedly killed in an airstrike east of Khartoum.[53]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF made further gains in Khartoum Bahri and advanced towards the El Mek Nimr Bridge, forcing the RSF out of almost the entire city except in Hillet Hamad.[54]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Renewed fighting in El Fasher killed seven people and injured 12 others. The SAF claimed that the deaths were caused by RSF shelling on the Abu Shouk camp. The SAF also claimed to have repelled an RSF attack on the city.[55]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the city of Umm Ruwaba in North Kordofan, advancing towards El Obeid.[56] It shot down ten drones over El Obeid[57] and retook Al-Azba and the eastern part of the Kafouri neighbourhood of Khartoum Bahri.[58]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 60 people were killed while 250 others were injured in an RSF attack on the Sabreen Market in Omdurman.[59] Two others were killed in an SAF airstrike in Khartoum,[60] while at least seven were killed by RSF shelling in El Obeid.[61] Eleven people were killed by RSF shelling on the Abu Shouk camp, while 13 others were killed during clashes in Nyala.[62]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the cities of Tambul, Rufaa and Al-Hasahisa in Gezira State.[63]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The JDF claimed to have repelled an RSF attack on El Fasher, killing 140 fighters and mercenaries, destroying 43 vehicles and capturing 12 more. The JDF also said that RSF fighters were appearing more on foot and on camels and horses, and also appeared to be under the influence of drugs.[64]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook Wad Rawah and al-Nabati in Gezira State.[65]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Renewed fighting and airstrikes in Darfur left at least 248 people dead or wounded. Health authorities believe the death toll is much higher than recorded due to the ongoing fighting preventing bodies from being recovered and counted.[62]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Abdallah Hussein, a senior RSF commander was killed by an SAF airstrike in al-Kamelin in Gezira State.[66]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have broke the siege of its Corps of Engineers garrison in the Al 'Aylafun area, and retook the al-Asaylat, Um Daw Ban, and Al 'Aylafun areas of the East Nile locality. The SAF said it plans to continue advances to recapture the Soba Bridge.[67]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: According to the state health minister of South Kordofan, the SPLM-N (al-Hilu) killed 44 people after shelling the main market, residential neighborhoods, and temporary shelters in schools in Kadugli.[68]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Twenty-five people were killed in an SAF airstrike in Nyala.[69]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least six people were killed by RSF shelling on the al-Nao hospital in Omdurman.[70]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken al-Kamelin[71] and laid siege to the town of Naima in White Nile State.[72]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Engineers from the Khartoum State Water Authority were fired at by RSF snipers stationed at the Kuwaiti building while they were assessing the damage to the Bahri Water Plant.[73]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the al-Rumaila district of Khartoum as well as the central mint.[74]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Five people were killed in SAF airstrikes in Nyala.[75]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the El Tekeina, El Maseed and El Noba areas south of Giad, the Saria Industrial Complex near Abu Hamama in Khartoum, and Wadi El Akhdar in the Sharg El Nil area of Khartoum Bahri.[76]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the Traffic Signs and License Plates Factory along with the entire industrial area of Khartoum. They also claimed to have retaken Al-Masoudiya in Khartoum state[77] and Abu Quta in northwestern Gezira State.[78]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have shot down seven RSF drones over Debba, Northern State.[79]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Three people were killed in an RSF attack on the Zamzam IDP camp.[80] Five others were killed in an RSF attack on Saloma, southeast of El Fasher.[81]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the Kafouri district of Khartoum Bahri.[82]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SLM and the GSLF launched an incursion into Chad from Darfur, resulting in clashes with the Chadian Army in the vicinity of the tri-border area with Sudan and Libya. Six Sudanese soldiers were killed while 13 others were injured. Three vehicles were also destroyed while two Sudanese commanders were captured and detained at Amdjarass.[83]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Transitional Sovereignty Council announced that a civilian-led transitional government would be formed once the SAF takes full control of Khartoum.[84][85]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 31 people were killed following two days of RSF attacks on the Zamzam IDP camp.[86]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 30 people were reported killed in RSF attacks on al-Jamalab and Na'ima in White Nile State. Fifteen others drowned on the White Nile river while they were boarding a boat to escape the attacks.[87]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: A 100-member RSF unit stationed in Al-Muzmum, Sennar State, surrendered to the SAF in Singa after previously fleeing to South Sudan.[88]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the El Nour Islamic Complex and the Bahri Thermal Power Plant in Khartoum.[89]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Ten people were killed in RSF attacks in Mellit Station in El Fasher. The SAF claimed to have destroyed an RSF base in the east of the city.[90]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF took control of the Kafouri area, the last RSF stronghold in Khartoum North, and the city of Er Rahad in North Kordofan.[91] It also retook the Ministry of Animal Resources, the Tax Tower, the Malaysian Tower, and the Medical Supply Department headquarters near central Khartoum.[92]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sudanese government extended the opening of the Adre border crossing with Chad until 16 May to allow humanitarian aid to reach Darfur.[93]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the Kober Bridge connecting Khartoum with Khartoum Bahri, as well as large parts of El Sajana and El Hilla El Jadeeda in southeastern Khartoum.[94]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF announced plans to form a parallel government in exile, the Government of Peace and Unity, in Nairobi, Kenya.[95]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: More than 200 people were killed following three days of RSF attacks in the El Geteina area of White Nile State.[96]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: An RSF assault on the Zamzam camp forced thousands to flee to Tawila.[97]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Six people were killed by RSF shelling in Omdurman.[98]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the El Hurriya Bridge in central Khartoum, as well as Sidra in North Kordofan.[99]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The United Nations confirmed a state of famine in the Zamzam, Abu Shouk and Al Salam IDP camps in North Darfur, as well as in two locations in the Western Nuba Mountains.[100]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Ten people were killed in an airstrike in El Khazan Jadeed, East Darfur.[99]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sudanese government recalled its ambassador to Kenya over the latter's hosting of meetings by the RSF and allied groups.[101] It also imposed a ban on the Saudi-owned Asharq News news channel, which was lifted on 24 March.[102]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF and the Sudan Shield Forces claimed to have forced the RSF to retreat from the Soba neighbourhood of eastern Khartoum and retook the Al-Lulua and Al-Samra neighbourhoods southeast of the Soba Bridge connecting Khartoum's southern and eastern neighbourhoods with the rural areas of East Nile, adding that the 17 RSF militants were killed while nine vehicles were destroyed or captured.[103]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF, the SPLM-N (al-Hilu) and allied groups signed a charter to establish the Government of Peace and Unity following a meeting in Nairobi.[104][105]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF's Sayyad Force lifted the two-year siege of El Obeid.[106] The SAF also recaptured El Geteina.[107]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have taken the eastern part of the Soba Bridge.[108]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF said that it had partially broken the siege of Dalang and captured the Al-Karkal, Koli, and Kiqa regions north of Kadugli and Hajar Al-Jawad and Karkariya to the south.[109]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have shot down an Ilyushin fighter jet over Nyala, killing its crew.[110] The pilot was later identified as Major General Abulgasem Ali.[111]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The National Umma Party removed Fadlallah Burma Nasir as its acting leader following his cosigning of the Government of Peace and Unity agreement with the RSF.[112] In response, Nasir ordered the dissolution of the party's Presidential Institution.[113]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: An SAF Antonov An-26 transport aircraft crashed into a residential area of Karari, Omdurman, during takeoff from Wadi Seidna Air Base, killing at least 46 people including Major-General Bahr Ahmed, a senior commander in Khartoum.[114][115]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF recaptured Al-Khiwai, advancing closer to relieve the siege of El-Khiwai.[116]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Food aid was halted due to continued attacks on the Zamzam camp.[117]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Russia called on the UN to support the Sudanese government's peace efforts and warned against the parallel RSF government that could halt efforts to support stability in Sudan.[118]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF launched a drone strike on the Merowe Power Station, leading to a power outage in the city.[119]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The JDF claimed to have intercepted an RSF supply shipment in North Darfur and "neutralized" foreign mercenaries, demanding apologies from Colombia. The claims were denied by the RSF.[120]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have dismantled a cell based in the Marabi’ al-Sharif area of Soba Sharq, east of Khartoum, that counterfeited currency for the RSF and included foreign nationals.[121]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook Station 13 and parts of the El Nasr and El Huda neighbourhoods in Khartoum.[122]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF reached the eastern edge of the al-Manshia bridge in East Nile, Khartoum and retook the headquarters of the East Nile Central Reserve Forces.[123]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Seven people were killed in an SAF airstrike on Umm Kuraydim, north of El Obeid.[124]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: More than 80 people were killed or injured by RSF shelling on Abu Shouk IDP camp.[125]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook El Dali and El Mazmum, the RSF's last strongholds in Sennar State, as well as Al-Jabalain in White Nile state.[126]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Sudan filed a case in the International Court of Justice (ICJ) against the United Arab Emirates, accusing it of complicity in genocide by providing weapons to the RSF.[127]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Canada imposed sanctions on al-Burhan and Hemedti, citing in part "an unwillingness on the part of the leaders to negotiate an end to the war".[128]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: A detention centre operated by the RSF near Khartoum was discovered, revealing evidence of torture and a nearby mass grave containing over 500 unmarked graves.[129][130]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Seven people were killed in an RSF attack on Al Khiwai, West Kordofan,[131] while two others were killed in RSF drone strikes in Al-Malha, North Darfur.[132]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have destroyed 47 vehicles and 100 drones belonging to the RSF in El Fasher over the course of 10 days. They also claimed that local forces killed 15 fighters and that they recaptured the whole Al-Salam neighborhood and the Lafat Taqro buildings in the south of the city.[133]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: 10 people were killed by RSF shelling in El Fasher,[134] while two children were killed and eight more were injured by RSF shelling in El Obeid.[135]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: RSF shelling on El Obeid killed one woman and injured four others, bringing the death toll from RSF attacks on the city to 32.[136]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sudanese government ordered a ban on imports from Kenya, citing national security concerns amid criticism over the latter's hosting of the RSF.[137]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have shot down a drone squadron targeting Atbara.[136] Eight civilians were killed in RSF raids on eastern Khartoum.[138]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Hemedti vowed to carry out new offensives on March 17, the anniversary of the RSF's founding, claiming the RSF had undergone several changes and had made alliances with other groups such as the SPLM-N. He threatened to invade Port Sudan and attack Atbara, Shendi, Merowe, Al Dabbah, and Dongola. He also said that countries supporting the SAF would "pay the price".[139]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The bodies of 11 people suspected to have been killed by the RSF were recovered from a well in the Fayhaa neighborhood of Khartoum.[140]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Government buildings used by the RSF in Ed Daein and Nyala were destroyed by missiles.[141] The SAF also claimed to have taken control of the Family Club, Khartoum 3, and part of Khartoum 2 and cut off the last RSF supply route to the Presidential Palace.[142]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Four people were killed and 30 people were injured including 18 children from RSF shelling in Karari, Omdurman.[143]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF said that its Armoured Corps had linked up with SAF forces at the General Command headquarters in Khartoum after clearing the People's Teaching Hospital from the RSF.[144]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The United Nations said the RSF detained more than 60 peacekeepers, abducted eight civilian staff, and seized eight vehicles and 280,000 litres of fuel from a United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA) logistics convoy heading from a refueling mission in Kadugli.[145]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sudanese government suspended development projects funded by Arab and international lenders, including the World Bank and African Development Bank, citing in part concerns over addressing arrears and resuming funding flows due to the ongoing conflict.[146]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have killed an RSF commander and 15 other fighters in an airstrike in El Fasher.[147]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have taken Al-Malha, which the JDF denied, adding that eight senior RSF officers, including field commander Colonel Ayoub Ahimer, had been killed.[148]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the Republican Palace in Khartoum from the RSF.[149][150] An RSF drone strike on the palace that same day killed six journalists including two military reporters and four members of a Sudan TV crew.[151]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the Corinthia Hotel and the headquarters of the Central Bank of Sudan and the General Intelligence Service in Khartoum from the RSF.[152] It also retook Tuti Island, situated at the confluence of the Blue Nile and the White Nile, after advancing through the Tuti Bridge.[153]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Forty-eight people were killed in ethnically motivated attacks by the RSF in Al-Malha.[154]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Eleven people were killed in an RSF drone strike on the Radwan Mosque in Hilat Kuko in East Nile area of Khartoum. Eight people were killed by RSF shelling in El Fasher,[155] while three others were killed by RSF shelling in Omdurman.[153]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Eighteen people were killed following three days of RSF attacks on villages in Gezira State northwest of Wad Madani.[156]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have taken Lagawa in West Kordofan.[155]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF launched a series of attacks in eastern Khartoum, killing at least five people and injuring dozens.[157] At the same time, the group retreated from the Salama, Azhari, Ad Hussein, Mayo, Gereif West, Burri, Sahafat and Kalakla neighbourhoods of Khartoum and were seen moving south towards Jebel Aulia.[158]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Darfur Initiative for Justice and Peace said that hundreds of civilians were killed in an SAF airstrike on the Tur'rah market near El Fasher.[159]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook Khartoum International Airport and the Manshiya Bridge over the Blue Nile in Khartoum. It also retook the Tiba al-Hassanab camp in Jabal Aulia, which is described as the RSF's last stronghold in Khartoum and its main base in central Sudan.[160]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Al-Burhan visited the presidential palace in Khartoum and announced the liberation of the city, proclaiming that "Khartoum is free".[161]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF reportedly cleared the last pockets of RSF control south of Khartoum and captured Jabal Awliya. They also claimed to have neutralized 23 RSF personnel and captured an artillery piece.[162]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: A swarm of drones attacked the city of Ad-Damazin in Blue Nile State, with some explosions and smoke being reported. The SAF claimed to have shot down five drones over the armored corps base, 4th infantry division headquarters, and the city's airport.[163]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the Souq Libya market west of Omdurman.[164]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF and allied fighters repelled an RSF assault on El Fasher and attacked a supply convoy, destroying 16 vehicles and killing dozens of RSF fighters. Nine civilians were killed and 17 more were injured in RSF shelling.[165]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Seven people were killed by RSF shelling on the Abu Shouk camp.[166]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have taken Khor El Dalaib in South Kordofan following clashes that left 12 civilians dead. It also claimed to have killed 70 fighters of the Islamic Movement, and destroyed or captured 13 vehicles.[167]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed by RSF shelling on the Abu Shouk camp.[168]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 96 people were killed following four days of attacks on the RSF on Al-Jumu’iya, south of Omdurman.[169]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have shot down an SAF Antonov aircraft over El Fasher, killing its eight crew.[167]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: More than 100 civilians were killed in clashes in Al Malha. The RSF was also accused of human rights violations after its capture, including looting, killings, and torture.[170]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Merowe power station was struck by an RSF drone, causing power outages in Omdurman and Northern State.[171]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 15 civilians were killed in clashes between the SAF and the RSF in Ombadda.[172]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Four people were killed in an RSF drone attack on Al Dabbah, Northern State.[173]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF launched a drone attack on Dongola Airport, destroying a fuel storage facility.[174]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Three people were killed by RSF shelling on Abu Shouk IDP camp.[175] Several others were killed in an joint RSF and SPLM-N (al-Hilu) attack in Rashad, South Kordofan.[176]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the Al-Nusour and Al-Konan camps as well as the Fatasha, Al-Hilla Al-Jadida, and Iskan Al-Safwa areas of Omdurman from the RSF.[177]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: RSF drone and artillery attacks in El Obeid and Al Dabbah killed 13 people.[178]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The ICJ began hearing Sudan's genocide case against the UAE.[179]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 15 civilians were killed by RSF shelling on the Abu Shouk camp. The RSF also claimed to have taken Umm Keddada.[180]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 32 civilians were killed in RSF shelling and drone attacks on El Fasher.[181]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: An RSF attack on Zamzam Refugee Camp killed or injured hundreds, most of them women and children. The RSF denied the allegations.[182]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have taken Zamzam Refugee Camp.[183]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF launched a drone attack on Atbara, hitting a fuel depot and a power generation station and causing blackouts.[184]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Hemedti officially announced the establishment of the Government of Peace and Unity.[185]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: An evening curfew was declared in El Fasher in response to RSF attacks.[186]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 57 people were killed by RSF shelling in El Fasher.[187]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF was accused of killing multiple civilians in an attack on the village of Broush in North Darfur.[188]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 30 people were killed during RSF attacks in El Fasher.[189]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 55 people were killed following two days of RSF shelling in El Fasher.[190]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: A faction of the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) led by Mohamed Bashara Yahya announced its allegiance to the SAF.[191]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 74 people were killed in an RSF attack on the village of Al-Zafa in West Kordofan.[192]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 11 people were killed in an RSF drone strike in Atbara that hit a displaced persons camp and energy facilities.[193]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: RSF shelling from Salha in Omdurman hit the SAF's general headquarters in Khartoum.[194]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF was accused of killing 31 people execution-style in Salha, Omdurman.[195]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: An RSF-allied militia abducted 40 aid workers and about 50 civilians who were evacuating the Zamzam camp.[196]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Forty-five people were killed following two days of RSF shelling in El Fasher.[197]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The first shipment of humanitarian aid from the UN arrived in central Khartoum for the first time since the war began.[198]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The UAE said it had intercepted millions of rounds of ammunition at an airport intended for the SAF.[199]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF took En Nahud in West Kordofan, killing 19 people.[200]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook the villages of Al-Sufi, Al-Alqa and Al-Shaqeeq on the west bank of the White Nile in White Nile State, while the RSF launched a drone attack on the headquarters of the SAF's 18th Infantry Division in Kosti.[201]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF said that the RSF fired several suicide drones towards Kassala Airport and Port Sudan, targeting Port Sudan Air Base and a goods warehouse and civilian facilities in the city, causing “limited damage”.[202][203]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF launched airstrikes on Nyala Airport following the landing of an aircraft believed to be transporting weapons to the RSF.[204]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The leader of the Otash IDP camp in Nyala, Abdel Razek Hassan Jalis, was shot dead along with his son and another camp resident in an attack by the RSF.[205]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The ICJ dismissed Sudan's genocide case against the UAE, citing lack of authority to continue the proceedings.[206]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF launched another series of drone strikes on Port Sudan.[207]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Six people were killed by RSF shelling on the Abu Shouk camp.[208]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sudanese government severed diplomatic relations with the UAE due to its alleged support for the RSF.[209]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF launched drone strikes on Port Sudan for the fourth consecutive day.[210]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Eight people were killed in RSF attacks on Omdurman.[211]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Fourteen people were killed in RSF shelling on Abu Shouk camp.[212]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sudanese government ordered the shutdown of the Greater Nile Oil Pipeline carrying petroleum experts by South Sudan, citing RSF attacks.[213]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 20 inmates were killed in a suspected RSF drone strike on El Obeid prison.[214]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the town of Al-Khuwayyi in West Kordofan from the RSF.[215]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Seven people were killed by RSF shelling in El Fasher.[216]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have retaken the town of Al-Hamadi in South Kordofan, as well as the Al-Jami’a and Al-Shaqla neighbourhoods in southern Omdurman from the RSF.[217][218]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF launched drone attacks on three electricity stations in Omdurman, causing blackouts across Khartoum.[219]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Four people were killed in a suspected RSF drone strike on an SAF hospital in El Obeid.[220]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Ten people were killed by SPLM-N (al-Hilu) shelling in Kadugli, while the SAF took Al-Tareeda and Al-Dakka in Qadeer, South Kordofan, from the SPLM-N (al-Hilu).[221]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Fourteen people were killed by RSF shelling on a market in the Abu Shouk camp.[222] One person was killed in an RSF attack on the village of Al-Samra in White Nile State.[223]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Nine people, including seven military personnel, were killed in an RSF drone strike on a base belonging to the Sudan Shield Forces in the Al-Butana plain of Gezira State.[224]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF retook Wadi al-Atrun in Al-Malha, located on a strategic road linking Northern State and North Darfur.[225] The SAF also retook Al-Salha in Omdurman, Al Alqa in the White Nile, and the Um Libana area in West Kordofan.[226]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: General al-Burhan appointed Kamil Idris as prime minister.[227]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF said it had cleared Khartoum State of the RSF.[228]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF said it had cleared White Nile State of the RSF.[229]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The US announced new sanctions on Sudan over the SAF's alleged use of chemical weapons against the RSF.[230]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF said it had found mass graves in Al-Salha, Omdurman containing the remains of 465 people killed by the RSF.[231]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF and its allies announced the capture of Ed Dubeibat in South Kordofan.[232]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: An RSF drone strike hit an SAF base and caused a fire at an SAF fuel depot in Kosti.[233]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Three people were killed in an RSF drone strike on a public transport station in Er Rahad.[234]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Eight people were killed in an RSF drone strike in Al Khuwayyi, while two others were killed in a separate attack in Dibebad.[235]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have retaken Dibebad and Al Khuwayyi.[236]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 28 people were killed in RSF attacks on El-Obeid, Dibebad and Al Khuwayyi. Among the dead were six people killed in a drone attack on a hospital in El-Obeid.[237][238]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: A World Food Programme (WFP) warehouse in El Fasher was damaged by shelling blamed on the RSF.[238]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 89 people were killed in an SAF airstrike on a market in Al-Koma, North Darfur.[239]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 13 people were killed in RSF attacks on West and South Kordofan.[240]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF launched drone strikes on Nyala.[241]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Prime Minister Idris ordered the dissolution of the transitional government.[242]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The Sudanese government and the RSF traded blame for an attack on a joint WFP-UNICEF convoy in Al-Koma that killed five people and destroyed several trucks carrying humanitarian aid.[243][244]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Fourteen people were killed by RSF shelling on Abu Shouk IDP camp.[245]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Five people were killed in an RSF drone strike in El Obeid.[246]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Six people were killed by RSF shelling on Abu Shouk IDP camp.[245]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: A Libyan National Army (LNA) unit crossed the common border into Sudan and reached three kilometers within Sudanese territory near Jabal Arkanu before clashing with an SAF-allied group, leaving two Libyans dead and others captured.[247]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF and the SPLM-N (al-Hilu) took the town of Um Dehilib, South Kordofan.[248]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF claimed to have taken the headquarters of the SAF's 22nd Infantry Division in Babanusa.[249]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF launched a widespread campaign of arrests across South Darfur and East Darfur.[250]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF accused the LNA of carrying out a joint attack with the RSF in the Libya-Egypt-Sudan border triangle.[251]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Eight people were killed in an SAF drone attack on a school sheltering IDPs in Abu Zabad, West Kordofan.[252]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF announced its withdrawal from the Libya-Egypt-Sudan border triangle following attacks by the LNA and the RSF the previous day.[247]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Eight people were killed by RSF shelling in Abu Shouk IDP camp.[253]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SLM-Minnawi accused the RSF of kidnapping 100 civilians fleeing El Fasher for forced conscription.[254]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF carried out a series of drone strikes on Nyala.[255]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Seven people, including five children, were killed by RSF shelling in El Obeid.[256]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: At least 35 people were killed by RSF shelling on an IDP shelter at the agriculture ministry building in El Fasher.[257]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF claimed to have repelled an RSF assault on El Fasher, destroying two armored troop carriers, two armored combat vehicles, and killing and injuring dozens of soldiers.[258]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The RSF took the oasis of Karb El Toum near the Libyan border.[259]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Fighting broke out between the SAF and the RSF in Babanusa for the first time since January 2024.[260]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: The SAF repelled an attack from the SPLM-N (Al-Hilu) in Kadugli.[261]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
content: Médecins Sans Frontières claimed cholera reached Darfur for the first time since the beginning of the war.[262]

title: Timeline of the Sudanese civil war (2025) - Wikipedia
