His genius was to repackage these antiquated adventures to fit the fashion of postwar Britain ... In Bond, he created a Bulldog Drummond for the jet age."[100] Umberto Eco considered Mickey Spillane to have been another major influence.[164]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: In May 1963 Fleming wrote a piece for Books and Bookmen magazine in which he described his approach to writing Bond books: "I write for about three hours in the morning ... and I do another hour's work between six and seven in the evening. I never correct anything and I never go back to see what I have written ... By following my formula, you write 2,000 words a day."[162] Benson identified what he described as the "Fleming Sweep", the use of "hooks" at the end of chapters to heighten tension and pull the reader into the next.[165] The hooks combine with what Anthony Burgess calls "a heightened journalistic style"[166] to produce "a speed of narrative, which hustles the reader past each danger point of mockery".[167]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: Umberto Eco analysed Fleming's works from a structuralist point of view,[168] and identified a series of oppositions within the storylines that provide structure and narrative, including:

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: Eco also noted that the Bond villains tend to come from Central Europe or from Slavic or Mediterranean countries and have a mixed heritage and "complex and obscure origins".[170] Eco found that the villains were generally asexual or homosexual, inventive, organisationally astute, and wealthy.[170] Black observed the same point: "Fleming did not use class enemies for his villains instead relying on physical distortion or ethnic identity ... Furthermore, in Britain foreign villains used foreign servants and employees ... This racism reflected not only a pronounced theme of interwar adventure writing, such as the novels of Buchan, but also wider literary culture."[171] Writer Louise Welsh found that the novel Live and Let Die "taps into the paranoia that some sectors of white society were feeling" as the civil rights movements challenged prejudice and inequality.[172]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: Fleming used well-known brand names and everyday details to support a sense of realism.[162] Kingsley Amis called this "the Fleming effect",[173] describing it as "the imaginative use of information, whereby the pervading fantastic nature of Bond's world ... [is] bolted down to some sort of reality, or at least counter-balanced."[174]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: The Bond books were written in post-war Britain, when the country was still an imperial power.[175] As the series progressed, the British Empire was in decline; journalist William Cook observed that "Bond pandered to Britain's inflated and increasingly insecure self-image, flattering us with the fantasy that Britannia could still punch above her weight."[100] This decline of British power was referred to in several of the novels; in From Russia, with Love, it manifested itself in Bond's conversations with Darko Kerim, when Bond admits that in England, "we don't show teeth any more—only gums."[176][177] The theme is strongest in one of the later books of the series, the 1964 novel You Only Live Twice, in conversations between Bond and the head of Japan's secret intelligence service, Tiger Tanaka. Fleming was acutely aware of the loss of British prestige in the 1950s and early 60s, particularly during the Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation, when he had Tanaka accuse Britain of throwing away the empire "with both hands".[177][178][179]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: Black points to the defections of four members of MI6 to the Soviet Union as having a major impact on how Britain was viewed in US intelligence circles.[180] The last of the defections was that of Kim Philby in January 1963,[181] while Fleming was still writing the first draft of You Only Live Twice.[182] The briefing between Bond and M is the first time in the twelve books that Fleming acknowledges the defections.[183] Black contends that the conversation between M and Bond allows Fleming to discuss the decline of Britain, with the defections and the Profumo affair of 1963 as a backdrop.[179] Two of the defections had taken place shortly before Fleming wrote Casino Royale,[184] and the book can be seen as the writer's "attempt to reflect the disturbing moral ambiguity of a post-war world that could produce traitors like Burgess and Maclean", according to Lycett.[185]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: By the end of the series, in the 1965 novel, The Man with the Golden Gun, Black notes that an independent inquiry was undertaken by the Jamaican judiciary, while the CIA and MI6 were recorded as acting "under the closest liaison and direction of the Jamaican CID": this was the new world of a non-colonial, independent Jamaica, further underlining the decline of the British Empire.[186] The decline was also reflected in Bond's use of US equipment and personnel in several novels.[187] Uncertain and shifting geopolitics led Fleming to replace the Russian organisation SMERSH with the international terrorist group SPECTRE in Thunderball, permitting "evil unconstrained by ideology".[188] Black argues that SPECTRE provides a measure of continuity to the remaining stories in the series.[158]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: A theme throughout the series was the effect of the Second World War.[189] The Times journalist Ben Macintyre considers that Bond was "the ideal antidote to Britain's postwar austerity, rationing and the looming premonition of lost power",[190] at a time when coal and many items of food were still rationed.[100] Fleming often used the war as a signal to establish good or evil in characters:[106][191] in For Your Eyes Only, the villain, Hammerstein, is a former Gestapo officer, while the sympathetic Royal Canadian Mounted Police officer, Colonel Johns, served with the British under Montgomery in the Eighth Army.[192] Similarly, in Moonraker, Drax (Graf Hugo von der Drache) is a "megalomaniac German Nazi who masquerades as an English gentleman",[193] and his assistant, Krebs, bears the same name as Hitler's last Chief of Staff.[106] In this, Fleming "exploits another British cultural antipathy of the 1950s. Germans, in the wake of the Second World War, made another easy and obvious target for bad press."[193] As the series progressed, the threat of a re-emergent Germany was overtaken by concerns about the Cold War, and the novels changed their focus accordingly.[194]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: Periodically in the series, the topic of comradeship or friendship arises, with a male ally who works with Bond on his mission.[195] Raymond Benson believes that the relationships Bond has with his allies "add another dimension to Bond's character, and ultimately, to the thematic continuity of the novels".[196] In Live and Let Die, agents Quarrel and Leiter represent the importance of male friends and allies, seen especially in Bond's response to the shark attack on Leiter; Benson observes that "the loyalty Bond feels towards his friends is as strong as his commitment to his job".[197] In Dr. No, Quarrel is "an indispensable ally".[198] Benson sees no evidence of discrimination in their relationship[199] and notes Bond's genuine remorse and sadness at Quarrel's death.[200]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: From the opening novel in the series, the theme of treachery was strong. Bond's target in Casino Royale, Le Chiffre, was the paymaster of a French communist trade union, and the overtones of a fifth column struck a chord with the largely British readership, as Communist influence in the trade unions had been an issue in the press and parliament,[201] especially after the defections of Burgess and Maclean in 1951.[185] The "traitor within" theme continued in Live and Let Die and Moonraker.[202]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: Raymond Benson considered the most obvious theme of the series to be good versus evil.[195] This crystallised in Goldfinger with the Saint George motif, which is stated explicitly in the book:[119] "Bond sighed wearily. Once more into the breach, dear friend! This time, it really was St George and the dragon. And St George had better get a move on and do something";[203] Black notes that the image of St. George is an English, rather than British personification.[204]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: The Bond novels also dealt with the question of Anglo-American relations, reflecting the central role of the US in the defence of the West.[205] In the aftermath of the Second World War, tensions surfaced between a British government trying to retain its empire and the American desire for a capitalist new world order, but Fleming did not focus on this directly, instead creating "an impression of the normality of British imperial rule and action".[189] Author and journalist Christopher Hitchens observed that "the central paradox of the classic Bond stories is that, although superficially devoted to the Anglo-American war against communism, they are full of contempt and resentment for America and Americans".[206] Fleming was aware of this tension between the two countries, but did not focus on it strongly.[189] Kingsley Amis, in his exploration of Bond in The James Bond Dossier, pointed out that "Leiter, such a nonentity as a piece of characterization ... he, the American, takes orders from Bond, the Britisher, and that Bond is constantly doing better than he".[207]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: For three of the novels, Goldfinger, Live and Let Die and Dr. No, it is Bond the British agent who has to sort out what turns out to be an American problem,[208] and Black points out that although it is American assets that are under threat in Dr. No, a British agent and a British warship, HMS Narvik, are sent with British soldiers to the island at the end of the novel to settle the matter.[209] Fleming became increasingly jaundiced about America, and his comments in the penultimate novel You Only Live Twice reflect this;[210] Bond's responses to Tanaka's comments reflect the declining relationship between Britain and America—in sharp contrast to the warm, co-operative relationship between Bond and Leiter in the earlier books.[179]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: In the late 1950s, the author Geoffrey Jenkins had suggested to Fleming that he write a Bond novel set in South Africa, and sent him his own idea for a plot outline which, according to Jenkins, Fleming felt had great potential.[212] After Fleming's death, Jenkins was commissioned by Bond publishers Glidrose Productions to write a continuation Bond novel, Per Fine Ounce, but it was never published.[213] Starting with Kingsley Amis's Colonel Sun, under the pseudonym "Robert Markham" in 1968,[214] several authors have been commissioned to write Bond novels, including Sebastian Faulks, who was asked by Ian Fleming Publications to write a new Bond novel in observance of what would have been Fleming's 100th birthday in 2008.[215]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: During his lifetime Fleming sold thirty million books; double that number were sold in the two years following his death.[1] In 2008 The Times ranked Fleming fourteenth on its list of "The 50 greatest British writers since 1945".[216] In 2002 Ian Fleming Publications announced the launch of the CWA Ian Fleming Steel Dagger award, presented by the Crime Writers' Association to the best thriller, adventure or spy novel originally published in the UK.[217]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: The Eon Productions series of Bond films, which started in 1962 with Dr. No, continued after Fleming's death. Along with two non-Eon produced films, there have been twenty-five Eon films, with the most recent, No Time to Die, released in September 2021.[218] The Eon Productions series has grossed over $6.2 billion worldwide, making it one of the highest-grossing film series.[219]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: The influence of Bond in the cinema and in literature is evident in films and books including the Austin Powers series,[220] Carry On Spying[221] and the Jason Bourne character.[217] In 2011 Fleming became the first English-language writer to have an international airport named after him: Ian Fleming International Airport, near Oracabessa, Jamaica, was officially opened on 12 January 2011 by Jamaican Prime Minister Bruce Golding and Fleming's niece, Lucy.[222] The Lilly Library at Indiana University houses a collection of Fleming manuscripts and first editions as well as his personal library of rare books.[223]

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: In 2023, it was reported that Fleming's James Bond series was being re-published, removing a number of racial slurs and references. A disclaimer was added at the beginning of each book, reading "This book was written at a time when terms and attitudes which might be considered offensive by modern readers were commonplace. A number of updates have been made in this edition, while keeping as close as possible to the original text and the period in which it is set."[224][225] Most of the original versions are available from Project Gutenberg Canada.

title: Ian Fleming - Wikipedia
content: Fleming's life is the subject of the 2024 biography, Ian Fleming: The Complete Man, that spans 864 pages and was completed with the help of Fleming's estate.[226][227] It was written by British novelist and biographer Nicholas Shakespeare.[228]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
section: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present)
content: This timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine covers the period from 1 June 2025 to the present day.

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Twelve Ukrainian soldiers were killed and 60 were wounded in a Russian missile attack on the 239th Polygon training ground north of Dnipro. The attack led to the resignation of Major General Mykhailo Drapatyi as Commander of the Ukrainian Ground Forces that same day.[1]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: During the night between 31 May and 1 June, Russia launched a large-scale air attack on Ukraine, with 472 drones and seven missiles according to the Ukrainian Air Force.[2]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Atesh claimed to have destroyed a relay box on the Volnovakha-Mariupol railway in occupied Donetsk Oblast.[3]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) conducted Operation Spiderweb which they claimed destroyed "more than 40" Russian aircraft, including A-50s, Tu-95s and Tu-22 M3s at four airbases, including the Belaya air base in Irkutsk Oblast, more than 4,000 kilometres (2,500 mi) from the Ukrainian border, following a drone attack launched from within Russia, near each of the affected bases.[4][5]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The number 68 Klimov-Moscow train was derailed when an "explosion" collapsed a railway bridge it was travelling on in Bryansk Oblast. According to Bryansk Governor Alexander Bogomaz, one passenger was killed while 66 were injured with 47 being hospitalised. Russian Senator Andrey Klishas, chair of the Federation Council Committee on constitutional legislation and state construction, blamed Ukraine for the incident. Another bridge explosion in Kursk Oblast led to a train derailment that injured one worker according to the acting governor.[6]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the rural settlements of Zoria [uk], Dyliivka and Dachne, near Toretsk.[7]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian Ministry of Defense claimed that Russian forces captured the villages of Kindrashivka and Oleksiivka in Sumy Oblast.[8][9]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: DeepStateMap reported that Russian forces captured the village of Kostiantynivka in Sumy Oblast.[10]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia and Ukraine held their second round of peace negotiations for 2025 in Istanbul, Turkey.[11]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Six people were killed in a Russian airstrike on Sumy.[12]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian-installed officials claimed that Ukrainian drone strikes on energy infrastructure caused widespread blackouts across Zaporizhzhia and Kherson Oblasts.[13]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU carried out an attack on the Crimean Bridge. The attack targeted the underwater supports of the bridge, with the SBU stating that the bridge had been mined over several months by its agents.[14][15]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of Andriivka in the Sumy direction and the village of Mykolaivka in the Pokrovsk direction.[16]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Zelenskyy appointed Mykhailo Drapatyi to become head of the Ukrainian military's Joint Forces Command.[17] Zelenskyy also removed Colonel Vadym Sukharevsky as commander of the Unmanned Systems Forces and replaced him with Major Robert Brovdi.[18]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU arrested a 42 year old conscript in Kharkiv who was leaking intelligence to Russian forces and planning to defect.[19]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: In the Sumy direction, Russian forces claimed to have taken the settlements of Varachyne and Yablunivka [uk], while geolocated footage confirmed Russian control over Vodolahy.[20]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian military intelligence (HUR) said it hacked the Tupolev design bureau's server, stealing some 4.4 gigabytes of data before replacing its webpage with an "image of an owl clutching a Russian aircraft".[21]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Five people were killed in a Russian drone attack in Pryluky, Chernihiv Oblast.[22] The Kherson Oblast State Administration [uk] building in Kherson city was partially destroyed in a Russian airstrike.[23]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian missiles struck a base in Klintsy, Bryansk Oblast, destroying an Iskander launcher and damaging two others.[24] According to Astra, 8 Russian soldiers were killed in the attack.[25]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have developed a FPV drone with a 50 kilometre range, using a fibre optic cable spool weighing less than 4 kilograms.[26]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Poland's Central Investigation Bureau of Police executed a search warrant on a building in the village of Laszki, following a report from concerned locals, finding "several" air defence systems and ammunition destined for Ukraine abandoned and unguarded in a warehouse.[27]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of Novokostiantynivka [uk] in Sumy Oblast.[28]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Six people were killed in Russian airstrikes on Kyiv.[29]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: An oil refinery in Engels, Saratov Oblast, caught fire after a drone attack. The local governor reported a fire at an "industrial enterprise". The Russian MoD claimed 174 Ukrainian drones intercepted over Crimea and 12 Russian regions.[30] Ukrainian drones also struck the defense plant "Progress" in Michurinsk, the fuel depot of the Engels-2 air base, Dyagilevo air base and Bryansk Airport.[31] Russian media channel Astra reported an Mi-8 was destroyed while an Mi-35 was damaged.[32]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Ukrainian Air Force stated that the Russian Aerospace Forces started using Tu-160 bombers to launch cruise missiles due to the loss of Tu-95 bombers from Operation Spider's Web.[33]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Andriivka in the Sumy direction and the villages of Vesele [uk] and Fedorivka [uk], south of Komar. Russian milbloggers claimed that Russian forces took the village of Novoserhiivka, northeast of Novopavlivka.[34]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The National Guard of Russia claimed that it killed a man attempting to target a military site in Ryazan Oblast with an FPV drone.[35]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Five people were killed in Russian airstrikes on Kharkiv,[36] while two others were killed in separate attacks in Kherson.[37] One person was killed in a separate attack in Synelnykove Raion, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[38]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Russian Su-35 was shot down over Kursk Oblast, according to the Ukrainian Air Force.[39]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Azot Chemical Plant in Novomoskovsk, Tula Oblast was struck by Ukrainian drones. Some eight explosions were heard by locals, a fire broke out and flights to Kaluga Airport were restricted temporarily.[40]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck a bitumen plant in Kstovo, Nizhny Novgorod Oblast, starting a fire of some 200 cubic meters.[41]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Canada announced an aid package worth US$25.5 Million which includes Bison and Coyote armoured vehicles, ammunition, and electronic warfare systems.[42][43]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian Railways' website was shut down by a cyber attack conducted by the HUR.[44]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones destroyed a Russian Buk-M3 missile system.[45]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: US President Donald Trump redirected 20,000 anti-drone missiles meant for Ukraine to American forces in the Middle East.[46]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed that elements of the 90th Tank Division had entered Dnipropetrovsk Oblast for the first time in an offensive.[47] Major Andrii Kovalev, a spokesman for Ukraine's General Staff denied that Russian forces had any presence in the oblast.[48]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia and Ukraine conducted a prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[49]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Four Ukrainian HIMARS rockets reportedly struck a Russian duty station in Rylsk, Kursk Oblast. The Acting Governor Alexander Khinshtein claimed a "cultural and recreational center" was hit by a Ukrainian missile, killing one person in Prigorodnaya Slobodka.[50][51]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck the Savasleyka air base in Nizhny Novgorod Oblast, reportedly damaging a MiG-31 and a Sukhoi.[52] Ukrainian drones also attacked a factory that produced parts for Shahed drones in Cheboksary. According to Astra a fire broke out and the plant was temporarily closed.[53]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Institute for the Study of War assessed that Russian forces had entered Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[54]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Krasne Pershe [uk] in eastern Kharkiv Oblast.[55]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Four people were killed in a Russian missile attack on Kyiv and Odesa.[56] In Kyiv, Boeing’s office was attacked, among other buildings.[57][58]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The governor of Belgorod Oblast claimed that one person was killed in a Ukrainian drone strike on Belgorod city.[59]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian Defence Ministry claimed to have shot down 102 Ukrainian drones over several regions. The drones targeted Shahed assembly plants in Nizhnekamsk and Yelabuga. Astra reported locals heard explosions while flights from airports in Nizhnekamsk, St Petersburg and Moscow were canceled temporarily.[60]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: HUR soldiers, with support from other units, ambushed Russian forces near Kupiansk, claiming to have killed 30 Russian soldiers, wounded over 40 and capturing two while destroying various fortifications.[61]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia and Ukraine conducted a second prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[62]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian military observer reported that Ukrainian forces retook the villages of Vesele [uk] and Fedorivka [uk], south of Komar.[55]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Three people were killed in a Russian drone attack on Kharkiv.[63]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A gunpowder factory in Kotovsk, Tambov Oblast was struck by Ukrainian drones as locals heard "multiple explosions" while a large fire broke out. The local governor, Yevgeny Pervyshov, said that the attack did not produce casualties. TASS said the drone attack was repelled, but a fire was caused by "Russian air defense systems".[64]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The bodies of 1,212 Ukrainian soldiers killed in action were returned by Russia.[65] A few days later, during the identification process in Ukraine, some of these bodies were identified as being the remains of Russian soldiers.[66]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The FSB claimed to have arrested an alleged Ukrainian agent on suspicion of plotting to assassinate a Russian war veteran using a car bomb in Veliky Novgorod.[67]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck the Rezonit plant producing Russian military equipment in the Zubovo technopark, Moscow Oblast.[68] The governor of Belgorod Oblast claimed that one person was killed in a drone attack in Borisovka.[69]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia and Ukraine conducted a third prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[70]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Atesh claimed to have killed several Russian soldiers in an attack on a military truck near Melitopol.[71]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Hryhorivka, northeast of Siversk in Donetsk Oblast.[72]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The bodies of 1,200 Ukrainians were returned by Russia as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[73]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian Defense Ministry claimed that Russian forces took the village of Koptieve, northeast of Pokrovsk and Komar.[74]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Buturlinovka Air Base in Voronezh Oblast was attacked by a Ukrainian drone. Local witnesses reported 15 blasts from within the airbase's perimeter.[75]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck the JSC NNK plant in Samara Oblast which produced explosives for the Russian military, and the Nevinnomyssk plant in Stavropol Krai, which made components for "explosives, ammunition, and rocket fuel".[76]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia and Ukraine conducted a fourth prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[77] The bodies of 1,200 Ukrainians were also repatriated as part of the agreement.[78]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Ukrainian Sapsan ballistic missile entered serial production.[79]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian military observer reported that Russian forces retook Fedorivka [uk], south of Komar. Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Horikhove [uk], east of Novopavlivka.[80]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: HUR agents sabotaged a power substation in Kaliningrad by draining the coolant out of the turbine resulting in a fire, causing an estimated over $5 million damage. Several nearby enterprises and military facilities experienced a power outage.[81]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Dmitriy Kurashov's trial commenced in Zaporizhzhia, the first trial involving a Russian soldier killing a Ukrainian POW, Vitalii Hodniuk in January 2024. Ukrainian authorities claimed to have identified the execution of 124 Ukrainian POWs by Russian soldiers.[82]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian HIMARS strike hit a Russian convoy in Makiivka, Donetsk Oblast. Local sources reported several destroyed buses and “a large number of dead and wounded”.[83]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: One person was killed by Russian shelling in Kherson.[84]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The head of Tatarstan claimed that one person was killed in a Ukrainian drone attack in Yelabuzhsky District.[85] The drones struck a Russian drone testing and production factory, according to the Ukrainian General Staff.[86]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The bodies of 1,200 Ukrainians were repatriated as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[87]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of Mala Korchakivka [uk] in the Sumy direction.[88]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Drones attacked Oryol city, with residents hearing explosions near an oil depot. The local governor claimed that eleven drones were "intercepted and destroyed" over Oryol Oblast.[89] In Kursk Oblast, the regional governor claimed that one person was killed in a drone strike in Goncharovka.[90]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The bodies of 1,245 Ukrainian soldiers were repatriated as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[91] However, Ukraine's Minister of Internal Affairs Ihor Klymenko claimed that some of the remains brought to Ukraine in recent repatriations were actually of Russian soldiers, whether "intentionally" or reflecting "habitual disregard for their own people."[92]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of Novomykolaivka [uk] at the border of Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[93]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: At least 30 people were killed and 172 injured in a Russian air attack on Kyiv.[94] Two people were killed in a drone attack on Odesa.[95]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The FSB claimed to have arrested a man in Kerch on suspicion of spying for Ukraine.[96]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ten explosions were heard in Kotovsk, Tambov Oblast, during a drone strike.[97]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces entered the village of Serebrianka, northeast of Siversk.[98]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Canada announced an aid package to Ukraine worth $4.3 billion.[99]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukraine's 225th Separate Assault Regiment attacked the command post of Russia's 30th Motorized Rifle Regiment near the village of Andriyivka, in Sumy Oblast some five kilometres from the Russian border. During the attack, the regiment claimed to have killed Russian Major Andrey Yartsev and seized documents. Images of some of the documents were uploaded to the regiment's Telegram account.[100]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The HUR claimed the assassination of the Russian-installed deputy-mayor of Berdiansk, Mykhailo Hrytsai with a silenced PM pistol. The HUR claimed that he had built torture chambers to suppress the local population.[101]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian forces took the village of Dovhenke [uk], north of Dvorichna.[102] Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Stupochky [uk], south of Chasiv Yar.[102]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck Volgograd, shutting down operations at airports in Volgograd, Saratov and Kaluga. The Russian MoD claimed that some 81 drones were shot down over some 10 regions from Crimea to Moscow. No casualties or damage was reported.[103][104]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia and Ukraine conducted a fifth prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[105]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Zelenskyy appointed Brigadier General Hennadii Shapovalov as commander of the Ukrainian Ground Forces.[106]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian court sentenced Arkady Gostev [ru], the head of the Russian Federal Penitentiary Service, to 10 years' imprisonment in absentia for the alleged establishment of torture facilities in Russian-occupied Kherson Oblast.[107]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: One person was killed in a Russian drone attack on Odesa.[108]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia and Ukraine conducted a sixth prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[109]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The HUR released a recorded phone call in which Russian soldiers talked about a missing comrade being eaten by a fellow soldier, citing it as evidence of cannibalism in the Russian army.[110]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU arrested a Ukrainian army deserter who had been recruited by the FSB and set fire to several military vehicles in exchange for rewards. It also found a Makarov handgun and 50 cartridges in a cache in connection to the arrest as part of an assassination plot against an FSB target in Kyiv.[111]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian forces took the village of Myrove [uk], northeast of Kupiansk.[112]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Six people were killed due to Russian bombing of Kramatorsk.[113]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of Oleksandro-Kalynove, west of Toretsk.[114] Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Zaporizhzia [uk], south of Novopavlivka and Shevchenko [uk], west of Velyka Novosilka.[114] Geolocated footage showed that Ukrainian forces retook the village of Andriivka in Sumy Oblast.[115]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: HUR drones struck a Russian fuel train in Zaporizhzhia Oblast, with photos posted online showing a break in the railway line.[116]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU arrested a Ukrainian serviceman accused of passing on the location of Neptune missile batteries.[117]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian training ground was struck by an Iskander-M missile, killing three people.[118][119]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian Ministry of Defense claimed that Russian forces captured the village of Hrekivka in Luhansk Oblast.[120] Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the villages of Komar and Perebudova in Donetsk Oblast.[120]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Nine people were killed in a Russian air attack on Kyiv,[121] while three others were killed in a separate attack in Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi.[122]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content:
The Atlas plant of Rosrezerv in Rostov was attacked by Ukrainian drones. The Russian MoD only reported a fire had broken out in the
Kamensky district while heat was detected by NASA FIRMS satellites.[123]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The bodies of three Russians misidentified as Ukrainian soldiers killed in action were repatriated after they were sent to Ukraine during a previous exchange of war dead with Russia.[124]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU claimed to have foiled two assassination attempts against President Zelenskyy by the FSB. One involved a colonel assigned to protect Zelenskyy. The second involved a "sleeper agent" in Poland that was to take place at Rzeszów Airport; the SBU worked with Poland's Internal Security Agency.[125]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Twenty-one people were killed in Russian missile attacks on Dnipro and Samar,[126][127] while three others were killed in a Russian drone attack near Verkhnia Syrovatka, Sumy Oblast.[128]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia accused Ukraine of setting fire to an apartment block in Krasnogorsk, Moscow Oblast following a drone attack, injuring two people.[129]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Malynivka, northeast of Pokrovsk and Novoserhiivka, west of Pokrovsk. A Russian source claimed that Russian forces took the rural settlement of Dyliivka, north of Toretsk.[130]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: ISW reported a potential Neptune missile strike on the command post of the Russian 88th "Hispaniola" Volunteer Brigade in Crimea.[131]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: In Crimea, explosions were reported in Dzhankoi, Kerch and near Cape Chauda. Local air defences were activated.[132]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck a Russian facility in Taganrog linked to drone production. The Russian MoD claimed to have intercepted 40 drones in several areas.[133]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukraine unveiled a glide bomb kit, with a range of 60 kilometres, that is a response to Russian KAB glide bombs.[134]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Ukrainian forces retook the village of Zelenyi Hai, east of Borova.[135]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukraine and the Council of Europe signed an agreement to establish a special tribunal to prosecute Russian leaders over the invasion.[136]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The HUR claimed it had damaged a Russian S-400 missile system in Crimea following a drone attack.[137]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The governor of Kursk Oblast claimed that Chinese journalist Lu Yuguang of Phoenix TV was injured in a Ukrainian drone attack on Korenevo.[138]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukraine and Russia conducted a prisoner exchange involving an unspecified number of POWs.[139]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Five people were killed in a Russian drone strike on Samar, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[140]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian MoD said it destroyed 39 drones over various regions of Russia and Crimea. In Kalachyovsky District, Volgograd Oblast, a bridge over the Don River was restricted to traffic after a fire was started by a drone strike. In Novokuybyshevsk, Samara Oblast, Rosneft's oil refinery was attacked. The local governor, Vyacheslav Fedorishchev, confirmed there was a fire but no casualties.[141][142] The SBU claimed to have destroyed two Su-34 bombers and damaged two more at Marinovka air base in Volgograd Oblast with long range drones.[143]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed in a Russian drone attack on Odesa.[144]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU claimed to have destroyed Russian three helicopters: a Mi-8, Mi-26, Mi-28 along with a Pantsyr-S1 self-propelled anti-aircraft missile and gun system following a drone attack on the Kirovske airbase in Crimea. Secondary detonations were reported following attacks on fuel, ammunition and drones stored at the base[145][146] while Atesh claimed to have set fire to a railway signal cabinet near Yasynuvata, Donetsk Oblast.[147]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: HUR drones struck the 120th Arsenal of the Main Missile and Artillery Directorate of the Russian Defense Ministry in Bryansk, with locals reporting explosions.[148]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A controversy arose in Germany over a €900 million apparent discrepancy in German MoD budgets for assistance to Ukraine. The MoD clarified that the apparent discrepancy is due to €900 million coming from the European Peace Facility, rather than from Germany directly.[149]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have crossed into Dnipropetrovsk Oblast and taken the village of Dachne near Novopavlivka. Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Zirka, near Komar.[150]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian F-16 was shot down and the pilot killed. The pilot, Lieutenant Colonel Maksym Ustymenko, used all "onboard weapons" and shot down seven aerial targets. The seventh damaged his fighter and forced him to fly away from a residential area before crashing.[151][152]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Russian drone attack in Kherson Oblast killed one person.[153]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Zelenskyy signed a decree withdrawing Ukraine from the Ottawa Treaty on Landmines.[154]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian MiG-29 bombed a Russian drone repair base using GBU-39 Small Diameter Bombs.[155]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of Novoukrainka, south of Pokrovsk and geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Novomykolaivka, at the border with Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[156]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: According to Astra and Russian media the acting commander of the 8th Combined Arms Army, Colonel Ruslan Goryachkin, was killed during a Ukrainian Storm Shadow strike on a command post in Donetsk Oblast.[157][158] Also killed was Colonel Vasily Skirnevsky, chief of communications for the 8th Combined Arms Army.[159]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Multiple people were reported killed in a Russian missile attack on Huliaipole, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[160] Zelenskyy later confirmed that the commander of the 110th Separate Mechanized Brigade was killed while 30 others were injured in the attack.[161] One person was killed in a Russian attack on a civilian evacuation vehicle near Pokrovsk.[162]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: SBU drones struck the Electromechanical Plant Kupol in Izhevsk, Udmurtia, some 1300 kilometres from the Ukrainian border, starting a fire according to locals.[163] The head of Udmurtia claimed three people were killed in the attack.[164] Ukrainian drones also hit Luhansk, Saratov and Engels.[165] An Su-30 was destroyed by HUR drones at Saky air base, as well as Pantsir-S1 missile system and various radars on Crimea.[166]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Oleksandr Syrskyi, commander-in-chief of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, ordered a ban on concentrating soldiers and equipment at training facilities and the placement of service personnel in tent camps as protection from Russian missile attacks.[167]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The head of the Luhansk People's Republic, Leonid Pasechnik, claimed that Russian forces had taken the entirety of Luhansk Oblast.[168]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The United States halted shipments of some key weapons to Ukraine, including aerial defence and precision guided munitions.[169] White House spokeswoman Anna Kelly gave concerns about American domestic stockpiles as justification.[170] Contradicting the statement, NBC later reported that Pete Hegseth stopped the shipment, supported by Elbridge Colby, although it would not have jeopardized the US military's own ammunition supplies.[171]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU claimed to have blown up a Russian ammunition depot in Khartsyzsk, Donetsk Oblast, following a drone strike.[172]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Three people were killed and over 47 injured in Russian attacks on Poltava that also set fire to a conscription office.[173][174] Two people were killed in a separate drone attack on Odesa that also damaged a building housing the Chinese consulate.[175]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Major General Mikhail Gudkov, deputy commander of the Russian Navy, was killed in Kursk Oblast by a HIMARS strike. Russian milbloggers claimed that some 22 were killed, while Primorsky Krai's governor Oleg Kozhemyako also confirmed the death of Gudkov's deputy.[176]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The governor of Lipetsk Oblast claimed that one person was killed in a Ukrainian drone strike.[177]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The former Russian-installed mayor of Luhansk, Manolis Pilavov, was killed in an explosion that also injured three people.[178]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU arrested a major in the Ukrainian Air Force, based in Lviv, accused of supplying the FSB with the location of military assets.[179]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The FSB arrested a woman on suspicion of trying to plant a car bomb targeting a defense industry worker in Saint Petersburg.[180]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: ISW referred to unverified reports that the head of the FSB's Fifth Directorate, Alexei Komkov, died in a car bombing in Moscow.[181]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: An aviation arsenal at Khalino airbase, Kursk Oblast, was struck by Ukrainian drones, leading to an explosion believed to include ammunition for the Pantsir-S1, one of which was "probably" damaged.[182]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces opened a new front in Kharkiv Oblast with the Russian defense ministry claiming to have captured the village of Milove. It also claimed to have taken the village of Razine near Pokrovsk.[181]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed in a Russian air attack on Kyiv.[183]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck Sergiyevo-Posadsky District in Moscow Oblast and several settlements in Rostov Oblast. In Azov several houses, a stadium and cars were damaged. In Dolotinka, Russian officials claimed that an apartment was struck and falling debris killed an elderly woman. Twenty residents were evacuated as well. In Shakhty 2,000 residents were left without power. In Moscow some four explosions were reported by locals resulting in a damaged power substation and 42,000 people without electricity.[184][185] A factory that manufactures warheads for Shahed drones was also struck.[186]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukraine and Russia conducted a prisoner exchange that saw the release of an unspecified number of POWs.[187]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A HUR bomb detonated in a Chevrolet Aveo, killing three drone pilots from the Russian Bars-Sarmat unit based in Strilkove, Kherson Oblast.[188]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the villages of Novomykolaivka [uk] in Sumy Oblast and Vesele [uk], south of Komar, the Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian forces took the village of Predtechyne, south of Chasiv Yar.[189] Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the villages of Koptieve and Shevchenko Pershe near Pokrovsk.[190]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck Cheboksary in Chuvashia. According to eyewitness the drones either attacked a warehouse or a local enterprise in the industrial area, causing explosions and a fire.[191] Drones also struck Engels, where it was claimed one drone was shot down and eight explosions were heard. Flights out of airports in Saratov, Ulyanovsk, and Saint Petersburg were canceled temporarily.[192]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Borisoglebsk air base was attacked by drones, causing a fire that was detected by NASA FIRMS. Locals reported 8-10 explosions.[193]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The HUR reportedly used explosives to destroy a gas pipeline along the Sea of Japan and water pipelines that supplied several military installations including garrisons of the 155th Marine Brigade in Vladivostok.[194][195]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Malynivka, in the Pokrovsk direction, Russian forces claimed to have advanced to the outskirts of Siversk.[190]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Five people were killed in Russian attacks on Kostiantynivka and Druzhkivka in Donetsk Oblast.[196]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia claimed to have taken the villages of Piddubne in Donetsk Oblast and Sobolivka in Kharkiv Oblast.[197][198]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: József Sebestyén, a Hungarian who was forcibly conscripted into the 128th Mountain Assault Brigade of the Ukrainian Army, died while on active duty due to wounds sustained from a beating by conscription officers.[199]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: In Moscow Oblast, the Krasnozavodsk Chemical Plant, which produces ammunition for Russian security forces, was struck by Ukrainian drones.[200]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: HUR drones struck "technological workshops" at the Ilsky oil refinery, Krasnodar Krai. Russian authorities acknowledged drone debris fell on the oil refinery.[201]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Roman Starovoyt, Russian Minister of Transport, was fired from his post due to "massive disruptions of Russian civilian airspace caused by Ukrainian drone raids". Starovoit, who previously served as governor of Kursk Oblast, was found dead hours later, having shot himself in an apparent suicide due to looming corruption charges.[202][203]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian forces has crossed into the Ukrainian border near Tyotkino and took the village of Bezsalivka.[204]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The governor of Kursk Oblast claimed that four people, including a Rosgvardiya officer, were killed in a Ukrainian drone attack on Kursk city.[205]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The US Department of Defense announced that it would send additional defensive weapons to Ukraine following a directive from President Trump.[206]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: In the early morning, Russia launched a large-scale aerial attack on Lutsk. Ukraine claimed the airstrike was the largest since the start of the war, with 728 drones and 13 missiles launched.[207][208]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Eight people were killed in Russian attacks on Kostiantynivka and Rodynske in Donetsk Oblast.[209] One person was killed in a separate attack in Pravdyne, Kherson Oblast, with the Ukrainian military claiming to have successfully targeted the responsible drone unit in Hola Prystan.[210]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU arrested two Chinese nationals in Kyiv on suspicion of gathering intelligence on the Neptune missile system.[211]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Ukrainian 3rd Assault Brigade claimed the world's first surrender of enemy soldiers to unmanned drones in Kharkiv Oblast.[212]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian translator working for the European Commission was dismissed from her position and subsequently detained by Belgian authorities on suspicion of espionage after allegedly taking prohibited notes of a closed door meeting between Zelenskyy and EU leaders.[213]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Tovste near Novopavlivka.[214]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed in a Russian drone attack on Kyiv[215] that also damaged the building housing the Apostolic Nunciature to Ukraine.[216]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The governor of Belgorod Oblast claimed that two people were killed in a Ukrainian drone attack on Shebekino.[217]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Atesh claimed to have carried out sabotage attacks on railway infrastructure in Uvarove in Crimea and in Volgograd.[218] The HUR claimed that it carried out an operation with Ukrainian partisans that destroyed a Russian command post in Melitopol, killing five soldiers.[219]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: SBU Colonel Ivan Voronych was shot dead in the Holosiivskyi District of Kyiv by an unknown assailant.[220] The White Phoenix, a local branch of the American neo-Nazi group The Base subsequently claimed responsibility for the attack.[221]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia started using "unmanned rail carts" and "remotely operated railway platforms" to reduce the loss of personnel from Ukrainian drone attacks on rail traffic operating near the front line.[222]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The US resumed deliveries of 155 mm shells and GMLRS to Ukraine.[223]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Russian decoy drone crashed in Lithuania after travelling through Belarus.[224]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian officials claimed that three people were killed in Ukrainian attacks on Belgorod, Lipetsk and Tula Oblasts.[225]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Zelena Dolyna in northern Donetsk Oblast.[226]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The HUR blew up a gas pipeline in Langepas, Tyumen Oblast, that supplied "military-industrial facilities" in Chelyabinsk, Orenburg, and Sverdlovsk Oblasts according to a HUR source.[227]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: UK intelligence estimated that Russian forces fighting in Ukraine had lost 236,000 soldiers killed or wounded in 2025, with 32,000 casualties (1,080 daily) in June 2025 alone.[228]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia launched a wave of aerial attacks across Ukraine, killing six people in Chernivtsi and in Dnipropetrovsk and Sumy Oblasts.[229][230] Explosions were also reported in Lutsk and Lviv. According to Zelenskyy, at least 597 drones and 26 missiles were sent by Russia,[231] while Poland deployed fighter jets to protect its own airspace.[231][232]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: One person was killed in a Russian drone attack in Sumy Oblast.[233]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: SBU head Vasyl Malyuk claimed that an Alpha team raided a safe house in Kyiv Oblast and killed two FSB agents responsible for the killing of SBU Colonel Ivan Voronych on 10 July, after they had resisted arrest.[234][235]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia claimed to have taken the village of Myrne [uk] in Donetsk Oblast, near the border with Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[236][237] and Dihtiarne [uk] in Kharkiv Oblast.[237]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Russian Buk-M3 was destroyed by artillery fire from the Ukrainian 15th Artillery Reconnaissance Brigade.[238]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: One person was killed in a Russian drone attack in Kharkiv Oblast.[239]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Malynivka, east of Huliapole.[240] Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of Yunakivka in the Sumy direction and Mayak in the Pokrovsk direction.[241]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The SBU claimed to have arrested a man in Rivne on suspicion of attempting to plant a bomb in an apartment building on behalf of the FSB.[242]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck a PJSC Energia plant in Yelets, Lipetsk Oblast, that manufactures batteries and accumulators for Russian weapons, resulting in a fire and one injury.[243]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Putin rewarded American citizen Daniel Martindale with a Russian passport for spying in Ukraine and the Order of the Donetsk People's Republic.[244]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the rural settlement of Novospaske, west of Toretsk. Russian milbloggers claimed that Russian forces took the village of Novotoretske, northeast of Pokrovsk and the Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian forces took the village of Voskresenka in Donetsk Oblast.[241]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed in a Russian airstrike on Dobropillia, Donetsk Oblast.[245]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The mayor of Ogre, Latvia, Egils Helmanis, was injured in a Russian drone strike in Ukraine while he was on an official visit to provide aid to the Ukrainian military.[246]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The governor of Belgorod Oblast claimed that one person was killed in a Ukrainian drone strike in Pervomaysky.[247]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Novokhatske [uk], southwest of Novopavlivka.[248]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck targets in St. Petersburg and Moscow. Drones interrupted flights to major airports, with ten flights being delayed in St. Petersburg. In Kaluga Oblast a 14-year-old girl was injured. According to the local governor a drone killed one man and injured some six in Belgorod city. In Smolensk Oblast one was injured. In Voronezh three children were claimed to have been injured. A total of 122 drones were claimed to have been intercepted by Russian forces.[249]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The bodies of 1,000 Ukrainian soldiers killed in action were repatriated by Russia in exchange for the bodies of 19 Russian soldiers.[250]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Lysivka [uk], near Pokrovsk.[251]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The HUR hacked the Gazprom databases, disabling access for some "20,000 system administrators", as well as copying and deleting "hundreds of terabytes of data". The data affected both the retail and service sides of the business.[252]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Hungarian government barred three Ukrainian military officials from entering the country amid a diplomatic dispute caused by the death of József Sebestyén.[253]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed in Russian attacks on Kamianske, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[254] One person was killed in a separate attack in Zaporizhzhia Oblast.[255]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Drones and explosions were reported in Moscow and Oryol Oblasts. In Moscow, Vnukovo Airport cancelled one flight and delayed multiple outbound and inbound flights. The Mayor of Moscow, Sergey Sobyanin, claimed several drones were shot down.[256] In Rostov-on-Don Astra reported a "massive fire" at a military barracks.[257]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: One person was killed in a Russian drone attack on Odesa, while two others were killed in a missile attack on Vasylkivka, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[258]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Mayor of Moscow claimed that 13 drones were shot down over two hours. Witnesses reported several drones shot down over Zelenograd.[259]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Atesh claimed to have carried out a sabotage attack on railway infrastructure near Medvedki, Tula Oblast.[260]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian air defense downed over 230 Ukrainian drones over Russia including 27 near Moscow.[261]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Yablunivka in the Sumy direction.[262] The Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian forces took the village of Bila Hora [uk], near Toretsk.[262]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian “long-range firepower” destroyed a S-300P and Nebo-M in Belgorod Oblast.[263]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: One person was killed in a Russian air attack on Kyiv.[264]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck Moscow and Rostov-on-Don. In the village of Kamenolomni, a train station and a flower shop were set on fire by falling debris. The mayor of Moscow claimed all drones were shot down. However flight restrictions were put in place at Moscow's airports for the fifth night in a row.[265]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian military observer Kostyantyn Mashovets claimed that Ukrainian forces retook the villages of Andriivka, Kindrativka, and Oleksiivka in the Sumy direction.[266]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: One person was killed in a Russian airstrike in Kramatorsk.[267]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Russian-installed Governor of Kherson Oblast, Vladimir Saldo, claimed that three people were killed in a Ukrainian drone strike on a bus in Hola Prystan.[267]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces entered the city of Pokrovsk.[268]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: In the Sumy direction, geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the rural settlement of Varachyne while Russian forces further claimed that they took the village of Oleksiivka.[269] Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Lypove, north of Lyman and Bila Hora, near Toretsk.[269]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Ukrainian Mirage 2000 crash landed in Volyn Oblast with the pilot ejecting safely, marking the first Mirage jet lost since their acquisition by Ukraine.[270]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Three people were killed in a Russian attack in Kharkiv Oblast.[271]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russia said that it agreed to exchange more POWs at peace negotiations with Ukraine held in Istanbul.[272]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of Torske near Lyman and the villages of Pankivka and Volodymyrivka northeast of Pokrovsk.[273] Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the towns of Radkivka [uk], north of Kupiansk and Dachne, south of Novopavlivka.[274]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: A Hungarian citizen who joined the Ukrainian Army in 2024 was charged in absentia "illegally joining an armed group involved in an armed conflict outside the territory of allied forces" by the Hungarian prosecutor's office in Csongrád-Csanád County.[275]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The US Department of Defense approved a military aid package valued at $322 million, including HAWK missiles, maintenance equipment and Bradley Vehicles.[276]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones struck several parts of Rostov Oblast, injuring three people, setting fire to the Novocherkassk power plant, and disrupting rail, Rostelecom and electricity services.[277]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Two people were killed in a Russian attack in Donetsk Oblast.[271]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Multiple buildings in Odesa, including the Pryvoz Market and historic buildings on Prymorskyi Boulevard, were damaged in a Russian airstrike.[278][279]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Ukrainian drones attacked Sochi and caused a fire in the Lukoil fuel depot with locals reporting at least seven explosions in the sky.[280] Russian air defence, ranging from small arms to S-300/400 missiles, engaged the drones "flying directly over residential buildings."[281] Two people were killed.[282]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: An Israeli Red Color radar designed to plot impact zones for rockets and drones and allowing for more timely warnings for civilians became active in Kyiv.[283]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of Yablunivka, northwest of Toretsk and the Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian forces took the rural settlement of Novoekonomichne, northeast of Pokrovsk and the village of Zvirove, southwest of Pokrovsk.[274]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The European Union announced that it was suspending all financial assistance to Ukraine until the "independent powers of its anti- corruption institutions are restored."[284]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
caption: No caption

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: One person was killed in a Russian airstrike on Kharkiv.[285]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The Ukrainian Air Force destroyed an FSB facility near Belaya Beryozka in Bryansk Oblast using AASM Hammer bombs.[286]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: The airports of Vladikavkaz, Grozny, Magas, Mineralnye Vody, Nalchik, Stavropol, Sochi, and Tambov were shut down due to drone attacks. Seventy flights were delayed, including 45 at Sochi Airport. In Nevinnomyssk, 30 drones were shot down by air defences. The local fertiliser plant, Nevinnomyssky Azot, was destroyed by Ukrainian drones. The Russian MoD reported downing 105 drones over several regions.[287][288]

title: Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 June 2025 – present) - Wikipedia
content: Astra reported 20 trains were delayed after a "drone attack". In Rostov Oblast, a train station and residential buildings in Peschanokopskoye were damaged by drones. Ten trains were delayed for five hours when power was lost. In Krasnodar Krai, 12 trains were delayed after drone debris damaged the power lines to the Timashevskaya station.[289]
